content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" includes provisions for various vessels such as COASTAL VENTURE and ASPHALT COMMANDER, as well as amendments related to maritime liens and certificates of documentation. SEC. 3 amends the Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996 by adding the vessel COASTAL VENTURE. SEC. 4 expands the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor. The Congress recognizes the significant contributions of the United States Merchant Marine in various wars, including serving as the Nation's first navy, keeping the lifeline of freedom open during World War II, and being praised as the "Fourth Arm of Defense" by President Roosevelt. Over 250,000 men and women served in the Merchant Marine during World War II. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine played a crucial role as the "Fourth Arm of Defense." Over 250,000 men and women served in the Merchant Marine, facing dangers from submarines, mines, and other threats. At least 6,830 members were killed at sea, 11,000 were wounded, and 604 were taken prisoner. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine played a crucial role, with over 250,000 members serving. At least 6,830 were killed at sea, 11,000 wounded, and 604 taken prisoner. 1 in 32 members died in the line of duty, the highest percentage among all US armed services. The Merchant Marine continues to serve the US, upholding the ideals of its former members. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds for an addition to the American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial Wall of Honor. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants to the American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial Committee, Inc., to build an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California. The Federal government will cover 50% of the costs, with an authorization of $500,000 for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to allow for recording and discharging liens on documented vessels. The Secretary must record a notice complying with the section if a declaration is filed stating the information is true and correct. When presenting a notice to the Secretary for recording under section 31343 of title 46, a declaration must be filed confirming the accuracy of the information and sending copies to the vessel owner, holders of existing liens, and mortgagees. The mortgagee of each undischarged mortgage on a vessel must file a declaration signed by an authorized official. Upon full discharge of the indebtedness, a certificate of discharge must be provided to the Secretary for recording. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions to declare a vessel lien-free. The Secretary must record a certificate of discharge of indebtedness. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions to declare a vessel lien-free, regardless of the amount in controversy or the parties' citizenship. Venue for such actions is where the vessel is found, where the claimant resides, or where the notice of claim of lien is recorded. The court may award costs and attorneys fees to the prevailing party. The Secretary must record a certificate of discharge of indebtedness. Venue for such actions is where the vessel is found, where the claimant resides, or where the notice of claim of lien is recorded. The court may award costs and attorneys fees to the prevailing party. A notice of claim of lien recorded under subsection (b) of this section shall expire 3 years after the date specified in the notice under subsection (b) of this section. This section does not alter the law pertaining to maritime liens or defenses thereto. The amendment to title 46, United States Code, includes changes to notice requirements for recording and discharging liens. The Secretary cannot refuse to approve surrender of documentation for a vessel based solely on a recorded notice of a lien claim. The approval may be conditioned for vessels over 1,000 gross tons. The Secretary may condition approval of surrendering documentation for vessels over 1,000 gross tons. Effective date of the section is July 1, 2002. SEC. 7. Tonnage measurement for R/V DAVIDSON as a small passenger vessel under title 46, United States Code. Applies when vessel complies with section 3301(8). SEC. 8. Miscellaneous certificates of documentation. The Secretary of Transportation can issue certificates of documentation for vessels like LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, and VICTORY OF BURNHAM for coastwise trade. The vessels listed include M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, SKIMMER, TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, and NOT A SHOT. The vessels listed in the curr_chunk are ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO. SEC. 9 amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, US Code to exempt SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10 deals with the certificate of documentation for 3 barges. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in coastwise trade for specific vessels, including former Navy and railroad car barges with specified dimensions. These vessels are limited to use as floating. The former railroad car barge TOMMY is 185 feet long and 34 feet wide. It can only be used as a floating platform for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR THE EAGLE. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for employment in the coastwise trade under specific conditions. The vessel EAGLE will be issued a certificate of documentation for coastwise trade under specific conditions, including being operated in conjunction with scour jet operations or dredging services adjacent to facilities owned by the State, political subdivision, or public authority, and clearly identified as a vessel of that entity. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE. Beginning April 1, 2002, 10 sailboats in the race can transport guests without payment until 60 days after the race ends or December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER may be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
